objtitle.title: The Body of Edward I in His Coffin, Two Finished Drawings

objinfo.objsize: 17.5 x 43.8 cm. including the frame lines

provenance.name: Society of Antiquaries, London
provenance.note: The Society of Antiquaries commissioned Blake's engraving master, James Basire, to execute this drawing. Basire assigned Blake to this task. The drawing was presumably delivered to the Society of Antiquaries shortly after its execution.

desc.objtitle:
The Body of Edward I in His Coffin, Two Finished Drawings,
Object 1 (Butlin 2)

objnote.p: A horizontal scale line in feet, with numbers 1 through 7, is inscribed below the designs. The pencil inscriptions below the frame line are later additions by an unidentified hand, possibly a curator. The collection stamp of the Society of Antiquaries also appears in the lower margin with a smaller collection stamp below the lower right corner of each coffin.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The composition depicts two detailed drawings of King Edward I in his coffin. Both coffins are unlidded and the king's body lies horizontally with head at left facing upward. In the coffin at left, Edward's entire body is shrouded although his crown and the bird atop his staff are still visible. In the depiction at right, his torso and face are uncovered and the open shroud drapes over the sides of the coffin. The king is bald and his eyes are closed. He wears a crown with three trefoils, a cape or drapery clasped at his right shoulder with a decorative pin, a long-sleeved shirt, and two decorative sashes that cross in front of his torso. His arms are at his sides and in each he holds a staff. His lower body remains covered in drapery. Four details of Edward's costume are included below the coffins and include, from left, a staff topped with a bird above three leafy decorations, a staff topped with a cross, a detail of the diamond-shaped decorations on the two sashes crossing the king's shirt, and the decorated clasp or pin from his right shoulder. A scale of seven feet is included along the lower edge of the composition.

component.illusobjdesc: The composition depicts two detailed drawings of King Edward I in his coffin. Both coffins are unlidded.

In the coffin at left, Edward's entire body is shrouded although his crown, decorated with three trefoils, and the bird atop his staff are still visible near his head. He lies with body horizontal, head at left, facing up. He is dead.

In the depiction of the coffin at right, Edward I's torso and face are uncovered and the open shroud drapes over the left and right sides of the coffin. The king is bald and his eyes are closed. He wears a crown with three trefoils, a cape or drapery clasped at his right shoulder with a decorative pin, a long-sleeved shirt, and two decorative sashes that cross in front of his torso. His arms are at his sides and in each he holds a staff. The staff in his right hand is topped with a cross and the staff in his left is topped with a bird and three leafy decorations. His lower body remains covered in drapery. He is dead.

Four details of Edward's costume are included below the coffins and include, from left, a staff topped with a bird above three leafy decorations, a staff topped with a cross, a detail of the diamond-shaped decorations on the two sashes crossing the king's shirt, and the decorated clasp or pin from his right shoulder. The two objects at right may be decorated with jewels. A scale of seven feet is included along the lower edge of the composition.
